1\. Requirements Catalogue

| **ID** | **Requirement Name** | **Detailed Description (What developer must implement)** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **FR-001** | User Login & Access Control | System must allow users to log in using email + password via Firebase Authentication. After login, system must detect user type (admin/staff) and load correct access screens. Invalid login must show clear error message. |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **FR-002** | Main Dashboard Navigation | After login, user must be able to navigate to core modules: Students, Teachers, Courses, Lesson Groups, Payments, Rooms, and Users Management from a central home page. |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **FR-003** | User Account CRUD (Admin only) | Admin must be able to create, edit, and delete system users using modal forms. Email, password, role selection must be validated before saving. |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **FR-004** | Student Registration & Editing | System must allow adding and updating students with full details including names, contact, parent link, and status. Validations required for phone number & required fields. |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **FR-005** | Teacher Management | Similar CRUD functions for teachers. Teacher info must store subject and assigned lesson groups if any. |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **FR-006** | Parent Management | System must allow creation and linking of parent records to student profiles. Parent must be stored with contact information. |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **FR-007** | Course Management | Admin must be able to create, update, view, and delete course entries with price, room, lesson group and schedule details. Course list must scroll smoothly. |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **FR-008** | Lesson Group Scheduling | System must support creating lesson groups per course, assigning teacher, room, and schedule times. Groups must show enrolled students and actions. |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **FR-009** | Attendance Recording | System must allow marking attendance for each student in a lesson group, storing date + attendance status in Firebase. |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **FR-010** | Room Management | System must support adding and listing rooms used for lessons. Rooms must appear selectable when assigning a schedule. |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **FR-011** | Payment Tracking | Admin must be able to record payments per student per course. Each payment must record amount, date, course & student reference. |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **FR-012** | Search & Filtering Lists | Screens listing students, courses, teachers or users must allow text-based filtering so users can quickly find a record. |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **FR-013** | Data Validation Enforcement | System must validate fields such as IDs, phone numbers, and required fields before saving to Database. Incorrect input shows inline error. |
| --- | --- | --- |

Non-Functional Requirements

| **ID** | **Requirement Name** | **Detailed Description** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **NFR-001** | Performance & Responsiveness | List screens must load data asynchronously from Firebase to prevent UI freezing. Scrolling must remain smooth with large record sets. |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **NFR-002** | Usability & UI Consistency | App must follow consistent UI design using Material components. Buttons, dialogs, icons and spacing should guide users with minimal training. |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **NFR-003** | Security of User Data | Firebase Authentication must secure access. Firestore Security Rules must restrict data updates based on user roles. Passwords never stored in plain text. |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **NFR-004** | Cross-Platform Compatibility | Application must run correctly on both Android and iOS without code changes, thanks to Flutter framework. |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **NFR-005** | Code Maintainability | Code must remain modular using folders: models, services, screens, and widgets. Data access logic kept inside service files for easy updates. |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **NFR-006** | Scalability of Data | Cloud Firestore database must allow dynamic growth in number of courses, users, and lesson groups without performance degradation. |
| --- | --- | --- |

2\. UML Activity Diagram![](data:image/png;base64,)

3\. Mobile Application Development Lifecycle

**Part 1 - User & Student Management**

This was the first feature developed because the application needed real data (students) before handling other modules. It took us **2** weeks since we were still learning Flutter and Mongodb properly.

Planning Stage

we talked with a training center admin to understand what they needed:  
They wanted one place where all students can be listed, edited, and removed quickly.

we created a simple sketch showing:

- Student List Page  

- Add/Edit Student Page  

- Delete confirmation pop-up  

Design Stage

we designed a student's table in MongoDB:

id, name, phone, group_id

This way, later features like groups or attendance could use the group_id for filtering.  
We also created a small UI mockup featuring a floating '+' button for adding students.

Implementation Stage

we wrote:

- student_list_screen.dart→ shows all students from DB  

- create_user_screen.dart → form to add new student  

- student_detail_screen.dart → update/delete student  

we used:

- ListView.builder to avoid lag when the list becomes long  

- DatabaseHelper async queries to keep UI smooth  

Testing Stage

we tested:

- Adding an empty student → shows validation message  

- Editing phone number → updates correctly in list  

- Deleting a student → asks confirmation (prevents accident)  

Deployment Stage

Exported APK for testing on my physical Android device.  
Scrolling and CRUD worked offline thanks to Mongodb.

**Part 2 - Teacher & Parent Management**

This feature took 1.5 weeks.

Planning & Design

Designed two tables:

teachers (id, name, phone, specialization)

parents (id, name, phone, student_id)

Parents are linked to students, so admins can contact guardians if needed.

UI sketches were almost identical to student screens → helped maintain consistent layout.

Implementation

The developer reused:

- Same CRUD logic from my student section  

- Same card layout for listing  

This shows good reusability practice

Testing

They checked:

- Teacher specialization updates correctly  

- Parent-linked student remains valid after editing  

**Part 3 - Lessons / Groups / Attendance Tracking (3 days)**

This part was a smaller development piece.  
Goal → allow organizing students into groups and record attendance.

Design

Added a group table:

id, group_name

Students are assigned to groups for future attendance.

Implementation

Simple UI for groups:

- See groups  

- Add group  

- Assign students to groups

**Part 4 - Payment & Settings Management**

This took 5-6 days, because it used the same CRUD structure.

Payment Section

Instead of online transactions, they stored:

- Payment date  

- Payment notes  

- Payment status (paid/unpaid)  

This keeps it simple but useful for admins.

Settings Section

Only admin settings for now:

- Password logout  

- About us section (static)

4\. Application Portability

Mobile application portability means the ability of an app to run smoothly across different devices, screen sizes, resolutions, and even operating systems without modifying the core code. In simple words, a portable mobile app should look and work the same on:

- Small phones like the Samsung A13  

- Large displays like the Xiaomi Note series  

- Tablets  

- Android OS versions from old (Android 8) to the newest (Android 14)  

For our project (User/Student section), portability was very important because students may use different Android devices at home or in the classroom.

How we Made My App Portable

Used AndroidX Support Libraries

we used AndroidX components such as:

- ConstraintLayout  

- RecyclerView  

- Firebase Auth & Firestore SDKs  

These automatically provide backward support for older Android versions.  
Example: The Login screen works on Android 8 even though we built using SDK 34 because AndroidX handles compatibility.

**Responsive Screen Layouts for Different Devices**

We created adaptive layouts so the UI does not break on small screens.

Techniques we used:

| Portability Practice | Where in My App |
| --- | --- |
| ConstraintLayout to auto-scale elements | Login + Register + Courses |
| --- | --- |
| ScrollView for long data | Course List, Student Profile |
| --- | --- |
| dp and sp units instead of px | All UI XMLs |
| --- | --- |
| ImageView set to adjustViewBounds | App Logo |
| --- | --- |

Example:  
The Student Course List rearranges properly when switching from phone portrait → tablet landscape.

**Screen-Specific Resource Folders**

To support different resolutions, we prepared:

res/layout/

res/layout-sw600dp/

res/drawable-hdpi/

res/drawable-xxhdpi/

Result:  
Icons and text are always readable - even cheap phones won't stretch pixelated images.

**API-Independent Firebase Backend**

Firebase services do not depend on the device hardware or OS version.

Example:

- A student logging in on Android 11 and Android 8 uses the same login code without changes.

**Testing on Multiple Devices**

We used **multiple emulator sizes** in Android Studio:

| **Device Type** | **Resolution** | **Feature Tested** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Small Phone | 720×1280 | Login, Home Navigation |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Modern Phone | 1080×2400 | Course Grid Scaling |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Tablet Emulator | 1280×800 | Schedule View |
| --- | --- | --- |

Everything worked without rewriting UI elements

5\. System and Hardware Requirements

Running Edu-Markaz requires straightforward system specs to ensure smooth performance without overwhelming devices. On the software side, the minimum SDK is Android API 21 (Android 5.0 Lollipop), which supports over 95% of active devices per 2025 stats, and iOS 11.0 for Apple users. You'll need Flutter SDK 3.19+ and Dart 3.2+ for building, with key dependencies like MongoDB (^20.3.0) for the database and http (^1.1.0) for networking- all listed in pubspec.yaml. RAM minimum is 2GB to handle list scrolling, and storage needs about 100MB free (app + growing DB).

Hardware-wise, an internet connection is essential for initial API pulls and syncs (Wi-Fi or 4G suffices), but offline mode covers basics. No camera or GPS is required in this version, though accelerometer support handles rotations naturally. These specs keep it accessible for most users.

| **Test Description** | **Expected Result** | **Actual Result** | **Comments** |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **Admin Login** | Valid credentials → Go to Admin Dashboard | Works as expected | Passed |

| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **Edit Course** | Updated course fields saved and UI refreshes | Works as expected | Passed |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **Delete Course** | Course removed from DB → List updates correctly | Works as expected | Passed |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **View Course List** | All courses load with no crash | Works as expected | Passed |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **View Course Details Screen** | Navigation to full course info screen | Works as expected | Passed |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **Search Courses** | List filtered instantly based on search text | Works as expected | Passed |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **Add Enrollment (Admin)** | Enrollment saved in DB and linked to course | Works as expected | Passed |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **Approve / Reject Enrollment** | Updates enrollment status and shows correctly | Works as expected | Passed |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **Logout** | Logged out → Return to login page | Works as expected | Passed |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **Dark Mode Button** | Should switch to dark theme | No functionality, only button UI visible | Not implemented |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **Change Language (Settings Screen)** | Should switch language in UI | UI text visible but no functionality coded | Not implemented |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
